topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the live-recorded episode and previews Shreyas’s “questions I wish I asked sooner” framing. They banter about the venue and the unusual setup compared to their first remote recording.

topics.title: Why Shreyas focuses on career questions
topics.summary: Shreyas explains he’s sharing questions he wished he’d asked earlier—and notes the harder part is being honest about the answers. Sets up the episode structure (three questions plus a bonus).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS (enterprise auth/SCIM/authorization) and Paragon (building and maintaining B2B integrations faster).

topics.title: Question 1: Why am I so busy?
topics.summary: Shreyas describes chronic stress from constant busyness and how productivity tactics eventually fail as scope grows. He frames scope as the “immovable force” that overwhelms even strong time-management systems.

topics.title: Annual planning is bloated without real strategy
topics.summary: Using annual planning as an example, Shreyas argues 4–6 week planning cycles are often wasteful and quickly invalidated. He shares how having a real, aligned product strategy at Stripe let him plan in days and avoid false precision debates.

topics.title: Busyness comes from weak product decisions
topics.summary: Shreyas explains how “two-way door” thinking can lead teams to ship low-adoption features, then get trapped into expanding them due to QBR optics and stakeholder pressure. The result is accumulating feature debt that keeps leaders perpetually busy.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Vanta (automating security compliance and trust management, including SOC 2/ISO/HIPAA and AI-assisted questionnaires).

topics.title: Question 2: Do I actually have good taste?
topics.summary: Shreyas recounts early-career beliefs at Google that devalued strategy, then how Twitter and Stripe taught him strategy is essential. He reframes “taste” as choosing sound beliefs and inputs—not just pixel-level product aesthetics.

topics.title: Building taste: resist metaphors, alliteration, authority
topics.summary: Shreyas argues real taste is recognizing quality before outcomes are obvious, and avoiding being swayed by catchy metaphors (two-way doors), alliteration (fail fast), and impressive-but-empty complexity. He emphasizes separating ideas from social proof to become a more critical thinker.

topics.title: Question 3: Why is my job so frustrating?
topics.summary: Shreyas describes PM leadership as lonely and introduces a three-level model: impact, execution, and optics. Frustration comes from spending too much time outside your “happy place,” especially as seniority forces more optics work.

topics.title: Align career choices with superpowers, not expectations
topics.summary: He shares choosing to cap scope (e.g., avoiding very large orgs) to reduce optics-heavy work and stay aligned with his strengths. Advice: make career decisions based on superpowers and authenticity rather than status, envy, or LinkedIn narratives.

topics.title: Bonus question: Am I really listening?
topics.summary: Shreyas challenges the idea that recap-and-eye-contact equals good listening, arguing there’s a deeper level that enables world-class leadership. He points to thinkers like Rick Rubin and Drucker as starting points for learning real listening.

topics.title: Wrap-up and outro
topics.summary: They close with logistics about Shreyas hanging around, thank-yous, a quick selfie, and Lenny’s standard subscribe/review outro.
